title: Heater's Island
desc:
(BIG)1699 - Burr Harrison and Giles Vandercastle visit the Piscataway village on Heater’s Island in the Potomac

The link(Piscataway,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piscataway_people) tribe settled in Fauquier County near Thoroughfare Gap in the late 1600s before moving into Loudoun County. Virginia officials Harrison and Vandercastle found a fort and 27 cabins providing shelter for approximately 300 people. This is one of the earliest recorded link(contacts,https://mdhistoricaltrust.wordpress.com/2015/04/24/heaters-island-piscataway) between Native Americans and white settlers in the Heritage Area.

title: Treaty of Albany
desc:
(BIG)August 22, 1722 - Treaty of Albany is ratified

Governor link(Alexander Spotswood,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Spotswood) of Virginia, the five Iroquois nations, and remnants of the Powhatan tribes agreed to a treaty, accepting that the Native Americans would keep their settlements west of the Blue Ridge Mountains. This treaty allowed white settlers to move into the Virginia Piedmont.
citation: Lewis Evans, A general map of the middle British colonies, Library of Congress

title: Prince William
desc:
(BIG)1731- An act of the Virginia General Assembly creates Prince William County The new county was formed out of portions of King George and Stafford Counties

The county takes its name from link(Prince William Augustus,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cumberland), Duke of Cumberland — a son of link(King George II,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain).

title: Waterford
desc:
1733 - The Village of Waterford is founded

Quaker leader link(Amos Janney,https://www.waterfordhistory.org/history/waterford-origins) moved to the Loudoun Valley in search of fertile land. Other Quakers soon joined him and founded the village of Waterford. The town soon had a mill, meeting house, and several shops. Within ten years, a second Quaker village — Goose Creek — was established in Loudoun County. Today both Waterford and Goose Creek (now called Lincoln) remain relatively unchanged and stand as models of historic preservation.

title: Chapman-Beverly Mill
desc:
1742 - Chapman-Beverly Mill is built in Thoroughfare Gap

Jonathan and Nathaniel Chapman built the link(mill,https://www.chapmansmill.org) and enlarged it in 1758. The mill processed wheat and corn, helping Northern Virginia’s farms prosper. Crops that passed through the mill went to Alexandria, where they could be shipped and sold to markets around the world.

(BIG)

title: Greenway Court
desc:
(BIG)1748 - Greenway Court Established

Located near White Post in Clarke County, Greenway Court was the home of link(Thomas Fairfax,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Fairfax), Sixth Lord Fairfax. He owned the land stretching from the Rappahannock River to the Potomac River and from the Chesapeake Bay west to the Appalachian Mountains, an area also known as the Fairfax Grant. He lived at link(Greenway Court,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenway_Court,_Virginia) from 1752 until his death in 1781.

title: Braddock Expedition
desc:
April 1755 - The Braddock Expedition marches through Loudoun County

In the spring of 1755 more than one thousand British soldiers landed in Alexandria under the command of General link(Edward Braddock,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Braddock); their mission was to drive the French from Fort Duquesne (modern Pittsburgh). Accompanying the force was a large number of Colonial troops and officers, among them George Washington, Daniel Boone, and link(Daniel Morgan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Morgan). A portion of the army marched through Loudoun County from Sugarland Run, through Leesburg, and westward to Keyes Gap. Braddock and his men met with disaster later that summer at the Battle of Monongahela.
citation: Route of the Braddock Expedition. *Campaigns of the American Revolution, 1775-1781 **1755 - Braddock's Expedition June-July 1755 From: [http://www.lib.utexas.edu/Libs/PCL/Map_collection/histus.html] "Courtesy of the University of Texas Librarie

title: Loudoun
desc:
(BIG)1757 - Loudoun County is created out of portions of Fairfax County, with the town of Leesburg as its seat

The County takes its name from link(John Campbell,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Campbell,_4th_Earl_of_Loudoun), Fourth Earl of Loudoun — a Scottish lord and Commander in Chief of British and Colonial forces for part of the French and Indian War. Leesburg was named for the former governor of the Colony of Virginia, link(Thomas Lee,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Lee_%28Virginia_colonist%29).
citation: Portrait of John Campbell by Allan Ramsay, 1747

title: Fauquier
desc:
(BIG)1759 Fauquier County is established out of the western part of Prince William County

Fauquier County is named after link(Francis Fauquier,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Fauquier), the Virginia Colony’s Lieutenant Governor from 1758 until his death in 1768.

title: Oak Hill
desc:
(BIG)1773 Thomas Marshall builds Oak Hill

link(John Marshall,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Marshall), future Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, became the owner of Oak Hill in 1785. He owned the home until 1835. 1774 - The Loudoun and Fauquier Resolves Citizens of Loudoun and Fauquier Counties met at their courthouses to draw up a list of complaints against the British. These “Resolves” opposed the British occupation of Boston and the taxation of the colonies without representation in Parliament.

title: Dunmore
desc:
]November 7, 1775 - Dunmore’s Proclamation is signed]

link(Proclamation,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunmore%27s_Proclamation) declared that enslaved people who joined the British armed forces would be freed. Several slaves from the Heritage Area followed link(Dunmore,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Murray,_4th_Earl_of_Dunmore)’s words and fought in the Ethiopian Regiment
citation: Portrait of John Murray, 4th Earl of Dunmore by Joshua Reynolds, 1765

title: Declaration read
desc:
August 12, 1776 - Declaration of Independence read in Loudoun County

The newly approved Declaration of Independence was Click link(read,https://loudounnow.com/2015/11/12/loudouns-revolutionary-spirit-memorialized-at-courthouse) to Loudoun’s citizens from the courthouse steps in Leesburg.
citation: Loudoun County Courthouse, in Leesburg, 1815 Christian Ignatius La Trobe Watercolor

title: John Champe
desc:
(BIG)1780 - John Champe’s secret mission

Loudoun County native link(John Champe,https://www.loudounhistory.org/history/revolutionary-war-john-champe) was chosen to undertake a dangerous secret mission. He was ordered to pose as an American deserter, join the British army, and kidnap the turncoat link(Benedict Arnold,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedict_Arnold). Champe did become a member of the British Army but did not capture Arnold. He escaped back to the Continental Army with valuable intelligence and became a hero.

(BIG)
citation: "John Champe on his way to 'desertion' ". First published by Currier and Ives. This reproduction of the original Chromolithograph is courtesy of the Loudoun Museum

title: War marches
desc:
(BIG)1781 - Revolutionary War Marches

In June 1781 American General link(Anthony Wayne,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Wayne) led a column of Pennsylvanians through Loudoun and Fauquier Counties to reinforce the link(Marquis de Lafayette,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert_du_Motier,_Marquis_de_Lafayette) in central Virginia. In the fall, nearly 3,000 British, German, and Loyalist prisoners from Yorktown marched through Fauquier County to Ashby’s Gap to prisoner of war camps near Winchester.

(BIG)

title: Daniel Morgan
desc:
(BIG)1782 - Daniel Morgan returns to Clarke County

link(Daniel Morgan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Morgan) moved to Virginia as a young man and settled near Battletown (now Berryville). During the Revolutionary War, he became one of George Washington’s best commanders, and he played a critical role at the Battles of Saratoga and Cowpens. He returned to Clarke County after the war, building a new home named Saratoga near Boyce, as well as the Burwell-Morgan Mill in Millwood. Devices known as “hornet’s balls” crushed ore in order to allow miners to get access to the gold.

title: VA ratifies constitution
desc:
(BIG)June 25, 1788 - Virginia ratifies the United States Constitution

Virginia Delegate link(Edmund Randolph,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmund_Randolph) sought his state’s link(ratification,https://www.usconstitution.net/rat_va.html) of the Constitution, and worked to achieve it. He later became the first Attorney General of the United States under President Washington. Randolph died in 1813 and is buried at link(Old Chapel,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Chapel_%28Millwood,_Virginia%29) in Millwood.

WE the Delegates of the people of Virginia, duly elected in pursuance of a recommendation from the General Assembly, and now met in Convention, having fully and freely investigated and discussed the proceedings of the Federal Convention, and being prepared as well as the most mature deliberation hath enabled us, to decide thereon, DO in the name and in behalf of the people of Virginia, declare and make known that the powers granted under the Constitution, being derived from the people of the United States may be resumed by them whensoever the same shall be perverted to their injury or oppression, and that every power not granted thereby remains with them and at their will: that therefore no right of any denomination, can be cancelled, abridged, restrained or modified, by the Congress, by the Senate or House of Representatives acting in any capacity, by the President or any department or officer of the United States, except in those instances in which power is given by the Constitution for those purposes: and that among other essential rights, the liberty of conscience and of the press cannot be cancelled, abridged, restrained or modified by any authority of the United States.

With these impressions, with a solemn appeal to the searcher of hearts for the purity of our intentions, and under the conviction, that, whatsoever imperfections may exist in the Constitution, ought rather to be examined in the mode prescribed therein, than to bring the Union into danger by a delay, with a hope of obtaining amendments previous to the ratification:

We the said Delegates, in the name and in behalf of the people of Virginia, do by these presents assent to, and ratify the Constitution recommended on the seventeenth day of September, one thousand seven hundred and eighty seven, by the Foederal Convention for the Government of the United States; hereby announcing to all those whom it may concern, that the said Constitution is binding upon the said People, according to an authentic copy hereto annexed, in the words following:

A copy of the Constitution was included in the ratification document.

title: Loudoun System
desc:
(BIG)1803 - Loudoun’s John A. Binns publishes “A Treatise on Practical Farming”

Binns' "Loudoun System" of farming promoted deep plowing, crop rotation, and the use of lime, gypsum, and manure. Binns’ progressive ideas spurred agricultural progress throughout the country, especially in the South.

title: Ashby's Gap turnpike
desc:
(BIG)1803–1812 - Ashby’s Gap Turnpike

Work took place on Ashby’s Gap Turnpike, from the Little River west to the Shenandoah River, including building the link(Goose Creek Bridge,https://bridgehunter.com/va/loudoun/bh50429).

title: Aldie Mill
desc:
(BIG)1807–1809 - Aldie Mill is constructed

Charles Fenton Mercer built the mill, the only one of its kind with double-overshot water wheels.

title: Warrenton
desc:
(BIG)1810 - Warrenton is incorporated

Fauquier’s county link(seat,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warrenton,_Virginia)  is named for Revolutionary War hero link(Joseph Warren,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Warren).

The settlement which would grow into the town of Warrenton began as a crossroads at the junction of the Falmouth-Winchester and Alexandria-Culpeper roads, where a trading post called the Red Store was located. In the 1790s, a courthouse was built in the area, and the location was known as "Fauquier Courthouse."
citation: Image from Harper's Weekly, courtesy www.sonofthesouth.net

title: Refuge in Leesburg
desc:
(BIG)1814 - Refuge in Leesburg

When the British occupied Washington on August 24, 1814, President link(James Madison,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Madison) fled the capital. Some of the nation’s most treasured historical documents were taken to Leesburg for safe keeping, including the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence. Tradition says that they were stored at Rokeby. Madison himself went to Belmont.

title: Gold rush
desc:
(BIG)1818 - Gold Rush in Fauquier County

In 1818, the first commercial gold mine in Fauquier County was created. Located near Sumerduck in southern Fauquier County, the Union Gold Mine was operated by Cornish immigrants who dug the mine’s 5,000-foot shaft. Within a few years at least 18 other mines were in operation. Mining temporarily halted during the Civil War, but resumed in the late 1860s and continued until the early 20th century.

title: Monroe Doctrine
desc:
(BIG)1823 - President James Monroe writes a draft of the Monroe Doctrine at Oak Hill

link(James Monroe,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Monroe) owned Oak Hill from the 1790s until his death in 1831. He likely wrote parts of the link(Monroe Doctrine,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monroe_Doctrine) from his link(Oak Hill,https://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/presidents/monroe_oak_hill.html) office.

title: Lafayette returns
desc:
(BIG)August 1825 - Lafayette Returns

To celebrate the 50th anniversary of the American Revolution President Monroe invited the link(Marquis de Lafayette,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert_du_Motier,_Marquis_de_Lafayette) on a celebratory tour of America. The “Hero of Two Worlds” arrived in Loudoun on August 6th, stopping first to visit James Monroe’s Oak Hill. On the 9th his arrival in Leesburg was announced by cannon fire and more than 1,500 townspeople came out to greet him. A few weeks later the Marquis visited Fauquier County, where he stayed at Norris Tavern in Warrenton before returning to Washington.

title: Clark/Warren
desc:
(BIG)1836 - Clarke and Warren counties established

Both were part of Frederick County before becoming separate jurisdictions.

title: Belmont Academy
desc:
(BIG)1836 - Margaret Mercer establishes Belmont Academy

The antislavery Mercer founded and taught at this liberal Christian school just east of Leesburg for local young ladies.

title: Piedmont Hunt
desc:
(BIG)

1840 - Piedmont Hunt established

The oldest foxhunt in the United States began at Old Welbourne near Middleburg.

title: RR
desc:
(BIG)1851–1859 - Construction of the Manassas Gap Railroad

By its full completion in 1859, the link(railroad,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manassas_Gap_Railroad) extended from Manassas Junction to Mount Jackson in the Shenandoah Valley.

title: Upperville
desc:
(BIG)1853 - Upperville Colt and Horse Show founded

Richard Dulany and others began this link(show,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upperville_Colt_%26_Horse_Show) to promote the good care of horses. It is the oldest horse show in the United States.

title: Wanzer
desc:
(BIG)

December 24, 1855 - The Wanzer slave escape begins

Frank Wanzer, Barnaby Grigsby, and four other enslaved people escaped north from farms near Aldie and Middleburg in one of the most famous episodes on the Underground Railroad.

title: Dangerfield
desc:
(BIG)April 6, 1859 - Daniel Dangerfield secures his freedom

Daniel Dangerfield was enslaved on farms and at the Aldie Mill before making his escape to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. Once there, link(Dangerfield,https://www.visitloudoun.org/things-to-do/civil-war/the-people/enslaved-who-escaped-to-freedom) found a wife and had a family. Dangerfield’s former owners caught him and brought him to Philadelphia for trial. Philadelphia’s abolitionists rallied and won his freedom in April 1859.

title: Harper's Ferry
desc:
(BIG)John Brown’s Raid on Harpers Ferry

John Brown’s plan to start an insurrection that would end slavery forever in the United States lasted only 36 hours and failed. Brown himself was captured and executed by the Commonwealth of Virginia. His raid spread fear and panic throughout Northern Virginia. It also inspired some slaves to act against their owners, including some near Berryville who managed to burn $11,000 worth of property on November 12, 1859. Clarke County’s link(Richard Parker,https://ohiohistoryhost.org/ohiomemory/archives/1414) presided over Brown’s trial. Brown was executed on December 2, 1859. link(Wikipedia article,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Brown%27s_raid_on_Harpers_Ferry)

Former Fauquier and Prince William County slave link(Dangerfield Newby,https://blackpast.org/aah/newby-dangerfield-f-1815-1859) joined John Brown in a desperate attempt to free his family but died in vain.
citation: Harper's Weekly Illustration of U.S. Marines attacking the firehouse

title: Secession
desc:
(BIG)Virginia’s State Convention adopts an Ordinance of Secession

Both of Loudoun’s delegates and Clarke’s delegate voted against adopting the ordinance, but it eventually passed by a vote of 88–55. The people of Virginia upheld the link(Convention,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Secession_Convention_of_1861)’s decision on May 23, 1861, by a vote of 125,950 to 20,373.

title: John Marr killed
desc:
(BIG)John Quincy Marr becomes the first Confederate officer killed in the Civil War

Marr commanded a company of soldiers stationed at Fairfax Court House. Union cavalry moved into the town and briefly fought with Marr’s Confederates. link(Marr,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Quincy_Marr) died in the fighting.

title: Troops move
desc:
(BIG)Confederate troops move to Manassas Junction by rail, the first time such an event occurred in American history

Confederate soldiers from the Shenandoah Valley boarded trains on the link(Manassas Gap Railroad,https://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Manassas_Gap_Railroad_During_the_Civil_War) at Piedmont Station (Delaplane) en route to the first major battle of the Civil War near Manassas Junction. Their timely arrival helped win the day for the Confederate Army.

title: Ball's Bluff
desc:
(BIG)Battle of Ball’s Bluff

The fierce link(battle,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Ball%27s_Bluff) outside Leesburg was a Confederate victory, with Union troops running down the bluff to the Potomac River. The commander of the Union forces, link(Edward Baker,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Dickinson_Baker), who was a U.S. Senator from Oregon, was killed. He is the only sitting U.S. Senator to be killed in battle.

title: Robert Scott
desc:
(BIG)Robert Eden Scott is killed by Union deserters

Robert Eden Scott served as one of two Fauquier County delegates to the Virginia State Convention in 1861. He tracked down two Union deserters in Fauquier County. One of them shot Scott, who died nearly instantly. link(Scott,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Eden_Scott) was so highly thought of that President Lincoln had considered him for his cabinet.

title: Battle of Front Royal
desc:
(BIG)

Battle of Front Royal

Confederate forces under Stonewall Jackson defeated a Union force at link(Front Royal,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Front_Royal), opening the door to Jackson’s capture of Winchester two days later.

title: Loudoun Rangers
desc:
The Loudoun Rangers are formed

link(Samuel Means,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_C._Means) and his Unionist link(Loudoun Rangers,https://www.loudounhistory.org/history/loudoun-cw-rangers) were officially mustered into Federal service. The Rangers were the only unit raised in present-day Virginia to serve in the United States Army during the Civil War. The Rangers suffered heavily in a fight with link(Elijah V. White,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elijah_V._White)’s Confederates at the Waterford Baptist Church on August 27, 1862

title: Escaped slaves
desc:
(BIG)Escaped slaves are photographed in the Rappahannock River

link(Timothy O’Sullivan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timothy_H._O%27Sullivan) captured a series of images showing five men and women seeking freedom within Union Army lines along the Rappahannock River. This image is one of the most widely used photographs from the Civil War. The photograph was taken near Tinpot Run Ford, just downstream from Remington in the Rappahannock River

title: Battle of Second Manassas
desc:
(BIG)Battle of Second Manassas

Union and Confederate armies once again found themselves squaring off outside of Manassas Junction. This second and larger battle at link(Manassas,https://www.history.com/topics/american-civil-war/second-battle-of-bull-run) involved 125,000 troops. Some 22,000 were either killed, wounded, or captured in three days of fighting.

title: Loudoun Campaign
desc:
(BIG)Loudoun Valley Campaign

Union and Confederate forces marched and fought in the Loudoun Valley in the wake of the link(Battle of Antietam,https://www.history.com/topics/american-civil-war/battle-of-antietam). Union army commander link(George B. McClellan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_B._McClellan) was relieved of his command and replaced by link(Ambrose Burnside,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambrose_Burnside) at Rectortown on November 7, 1862.

title: Mosby's Rangers
desc:
(BIG)

Mosby’s Rangers are officially formed

link(John Mosby,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_S._Mosby) officially formed link(Co. A, 43rd Battalion of Virginia Cavalry,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/43rd_Battalion,_Virginia_Cavalry) at Rector’s Crossroads (pictured). Mosby’s command operated for 28 months in Northern Virginia, gathering intelligence and harassing Union supply lines throughout the region.

booklet(Booklet on Mosby's life,mcbook)

title: Aldie, Middleburg & Upperville
desc:
(BIG)Battles of Aldie, Middleburg, and Upperville

During the second Confederate invasion of the North, opposing Union and Confederate cavalry clashed inconclusively in the Loudoun Valley in link(Aldie,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Aldie), link(Middleburg,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Middleburg), and link(Upperville,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Upperville) for five days. The two armies faced each other again at Gettysburg in July.

title: Waterford News
desc:
The Waterford News is published for the first time

Three Quaker girls in Waterford published eight issues of a Union sympathizing link(newspaper,https://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaxtf/view?docId=tbl/viletbl00027.xml) within Confederate territory. The proceeds from the newspaper supported sick and wounded Union soldiers. Some sources claim the venture raised more than $1,000.

title: Cool Spring
desc:
(BIG)Battle of Cool Spring

Following the Confederate move into Maryland under General Jubal Early in July 1864 and the brief fighting in Washington, D.C., the Southerners recrossed the Potomac River near Leesburg and headed to the Shenandoah Valley. Pursuing Federal forces caught up with the Confederates along the Shenandoah River on the Blue Ridge Mountain’s western slopes. The resulting link(battle at Cool Spring,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Cool_Spring), a Confederate victory, was the largest battle of the war in Clarke County.

title: Laws & Wright
desc:
(BIG)Thomas Laws and Rebecca Wright aid the Union war effort in the Shenandoah Valley

link(Thomas Laws,https://www.localdvm.com/news/virginia/story-of-enslaved-clarke-county-man-who-acted-as-spy-during-the-civil-war/905658468), a Clarke County slave, helped Union link(Gen. Philip Sheridan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Sheridan) learn about Confederate forces in the Shenandoah Valley. Laws walked through Confederate lines and met with Quaker schoolteacher link(Rebecca Wright,https://www.civilwarwomenblog.com/rebecca-wright) in Winchester. Wright supplied Laws with intelligence about the Confederates and Laws brought that back to Sheridan. This contributed significantly to the Union successes in the Shenandoah Valley in the fall of 1864.

title: Mosby's Rangers executed
desc:
(BIG)Mosby’s Rangers executed

Union soldiers executed six of Mosby’s Rangers in the streets of Front Royal by order of United States link(General Alfred Torbert,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Thomas_Archimedes_Torbert). One more was hanged on October 14. The executions took place following a Confederate raid on a Union ambulance train near Front Royal.

title: Mosby retaliates
desc:
(BIG)Mosby retaliates

In retaliation for the Front Royal executions, John S. Mosby ordered the executions of seven Union soldiers, selected by lottery, outside Berryville. Ultimately, three Union prisoners were hanged, two were shot (and survived), and two escaped.

title: Burning raid
desc:
(BIG)The Burning Raid

Federal cavalrymen rode through the Loudoun and northern Crooked Run valleys burning barns, mills, and stables to prevent the further use of both valleys as a staging point for Mosby’s Rangers. During the five-day raid, an estimated $6.4 million (in 2017 currency) of property was torched or carried off by the cavalrymen.

title: Freedman's Bureau
desc:
(BIG)Freedmen’s Bureau established

The U.S. Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen and Abandoned Lands, known better as the link(Freedmen’s Bureau,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedmen%27s_Bureau), began working with former slaves and poor whites in the South. Freedmen’s Bureau offices were established in Middleburg, Manassas, Warrenton, and Front Royal.

title: Civil War ends
desc:
(BIG)Lee surrenders at Appomattox

link(Robert E. Lee,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_E._Lee) surrendered his Confederate Army to link(Ulysses S. Grant,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant) at link(Appomattox Courthouse,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House) effectively signaling the end of the Civil War. Mosby disbanded his command in Salem, today’s Marshall, on April 21, 1865.

title: Holmes
desc:
(BIG)African American veteran John Holmes establishes a freedmen’s school in Millwood

Civil War veteran link(John Holmes,https://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Holmes_Joseph_R_ca_1838-May_3_1869) lost a leg while fighting for the Federal cause in the Civil War. By July 1869, Holmes was teaching at the African American school in Millwood.

title: Josephine City
desc:
(BIG)Josephine City is formed

31 acres of land formerly belonging to the estate of Edward McCormick was auctioned off to black residents of Berryville. The land later became known as link(Josephine City,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephine_City_Historic_District).

title: Manassas
desc:
(BIG)Manassas incorporated

Manassas became Prince William’s county seat in 1892.

title: Emancipation Association
desc:
(BIG)The Loudoun County Emancipation Association founded

A handful of men meeting in Hamilton sought a formalized way to memorialize the announcement of Lincoln’s Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation (September 22, 1862). They formed the Loudoun County Emancipation Association. The Association purchased land south of Purcellville to hold its celebrations, and celebrated Emancipation Day until 1967.

title: Prohibition
desc:
(BIG)

The Prohibition and Evangelical Association of Loudoun formed

Religious gatherings known as Bush Meetings took place in Purcellville beginning in 1877. Meetings became formalized under the title of the Prohibition and Evangelical Association of Loudoun. Bush Meetings ended in Loudoun in the early 1930s.

title: Great Hound Match
desc:
(BIG)The Great Hound Match of 1905

To end a heated debate about whether American or English hounds were better suited to foxhunting in North America, Harry Worcester Smith and his Grafton Hunt (American hounds) faced off against Henry Higginson and the Middlesex Hunt (English hounds). The match had a wide following. At the end of nearly two weeks of hunting, neither Hunt caught a fox, but the judges awarded the victory to Smith and his American-bred hounds. The match greatly elevated Northern Virginia’s profile as hunt country.

title: Theodore Roosevelt
desc:
(BIG)

President Theodore Roosevelt sets a record

link(Theodore Roosevelt,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt) and several aides completed a one-day, 104-mile horseback ride from Washington, D.C., to Warrenton and back. President Roosevelt feasted on a lunch at the Warren Green Hotel, made a speech, and continued his ride back to Washington. “It was bully!” Roosevelt said on his arrival at the Executive Mansion.

title: Warrenton Fire
desc:
(BIG)Fire sweeps through downtown Warrenton

A massive fire devastated Warrenton, burning 26 buildings and leaving 14 families homeless.

title: World War I
desc:
(BIG)America participates in World War I

World War I’s shockwaves reached far and wide, claiming the lives of 122 citizens of the Heritage Area. Loudoun native link(Westmoreland Davis,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westmoreland_Davis) served as Virginia’s wartime governor.

title: Mary Mallory dies
desc:
(BIG)

Freedwoman Mary Mallory dies at the age of 108

Mary Mallory spent the first 52 years of her life as an enslaved woman at Morven Park but lived as a free person for her last 56 years. She lived out her life in Leesburg
and is buried in the Mount Zion Community Cemetery.

title: Rosemont
desc:
(BIG)Harry Flood Byrd, Sr. purchases Rosemont

Virginia Governor (1926-1930) and Senator (1933-1965) Harry Flood Byrd, Sr. purchased Rosemont outside Berryville. He moved in by 1929. Byrd is best known for his improvements to Virginia’s highways and tourism sites, but also for his role in instituting a “link(massive resistance,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massive_resistance)” policy in Virginia to oppose the integration of the state’s schools.

title: Skyline Drive extended
desc:
(BIG)Skyline Drive extended to Front Royal

The scenic link(Skyline Drive,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skyline_Drive) running along the spine of the Blue Ridge Mountains reached Front Royal. It took eight years (1931-1939) to complete the roadway as part of the Works Progress Administration’s New Deal initiatives.

title: World War II
desc:
(BIG)Local men and women participate in World War II

link(World War II,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II) had an impact on the whole globe, including the Heritage Area. Clarke, Fauquier, Loudoun, Prince William, and Warren counties lost 288 residents in the war while citizens at home endured rationing, “victory” link(speed limits,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Maximum_Speed_Law), and constant worrying about their loved ones far away.

title: Truman visits Ball's Bluff
desc:
(BIG)President Truman visits Ball’s Bluff

link(Harry Truman,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_S._Truman came to Leesburg to visit Secretary of State link(George C. Marshall,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Marshall). Together, the two toured the Ball’s Bluff battlefield before returning to Marshall’s home and discussed China, Russia, public people and their lives. Marshall lived at Dodona Manor in Leesburg from 1941 to his death in 1959

title: Massive Resistance
desc:
(BIG)Warren County High School is a symbol of “massive resistance” and integration

Ordered to integrate in the wake of the landmark case Brown v. Board of Education, Virginia Governor Almond instead closed Warren County High School in September 1958 as part of the state’s “link(massive resistance,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massive_resistance)” policy to integration. After the school reopened, 23 African American students enrolled on February 18, 1959.

title: Kennedy
desc:
(BIG)The Kennedy family arrives in Hunt Country

Spurred by a love of horse country, President link(John F. Kennedy,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy) and First Lady link(Jackie,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis) leased Glen Ora, south of Middleburg, as their weekend retreat. The Kennedys were frequent visitors to Middleburg and later built their own home, Wexford, south of Atoka. The family did not spend much time at Wexford. Shortly after its completion, President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas.

title: Desegregation
desc:
(BIG)Restaurants in Middleburg are desegregated

Hoping to take advantage of the news media flocking to Middleburg to cover President Kennedy, two Howard University students took seats at Flournoy’s Drugstore. The owners refused them service. The rejected students boldly sought to organize a larger sit-in that coincided with the Kennedy’s — and the media’s — next visit to Middleburg. Seeking to avoid a confrontation in front of the President and spare Middleburg the embarrassment, restaurant owners backed down. On April 9, two local black customers sat down at Flournoy’s Drugstore and were served.

title: Dulles opens
desc:
(BIG)Dulles Airport opens

Dulles International Airport’s construction and opening spurred the growth of eastern Loudoun’s population, but it altered the area’s agricultural character. link(Dulles,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Dulles_International_Airport) attracted large commercial development by the 1990s.

title: Poor People's Campaign
desc:
(BIG)September 17, 1967 - Martin Luther King, Jr. and other prominent leaders organize the Poor People’s Campaign

Meeting at Airlie outside of Warrenton, Civil Rights leader Martin Luther link(King,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.), Jr. and the Southern Christian Leadership link(Conference,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Christian_Leadership_Conference) planned the Poor People’s link(Campaign,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poor_People%27s_Campaign), a movement organized to achieve economic justice in the United States for underprivileged individuals.

title: TWA 514 crash
desc:
(BIG)TWA Flight 514 crashes at Mt. Weather

Diverted to Dulles International Airport and beginning its descent on the stormy day of December 1, 1974, link(TWA Flight 514,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TWA_Flight_514) collided into the western side of the Blue Ridge Mountains near Mt. Weather at 11:09 am, killing all 92 passengers and crew members. The crash brought unwanted attention to the top secret government facility at link(Mt. Weather,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Weather_Emergency_Operations_Center), a relocation site for government officials in the case of national disaster.

title: MHAA founded
desc:
(BIG)The Mosby Heritage Area Association is founded

MHAA’s mission is to educate and advocate for the preservation of the extraordinary historical landscape and culture of the Mosby Heritage Area for future generations.

title: Introduction
desc:
The Mosby Heritage Area is a region rich with history that spans centuries. From daring escapes on the Underground Railroad to Civil War battles to visits of prominent foreign dignitaries, Northern Virginia's Piedmont and the Lower Shenandoah Valley have seen history. These stories can still be experienced today in the region's historic landscapes, towns, and villages.

How to view this project

The timeline is divided into seven periods, indicated by grey horizontal bars. Clicking on one will focus in on that time period. Clicking on "Show all" button with show all the periods and along with this pane you're reading now.

Clicking on the dots in the timeline or the map will move the map to highlight the location and also put up a popup dialog with information, images, and links for more information on the web. Clicking on a popup will enlarge it, and clicking again will show the picture alone and much larger.

Clicking on the (x) in the upper right of the dialog box will close it, so you can explore the map below. Clicking outside of the dialog box will also close it.

Any underlined words are links to other websites, including many from Wikipedia that will offer historical context in a box over the map area, or in a new browser tab.

The map is panned by dragging it across the screen. Use the mouse wheel or buttons in the upper-left corner to zoom in and out

title: Early America
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4810/44259178380_389f821b14_z_d.jpg)9,500 BC – 8,000 BC - Paleoindians occupy the Thunderbird and Flint Run sites along the Shenandoah Rive near Front Royal

Archaeologists estimate that villages along the Shenandoah River housed hundreds of link(people,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paleo-Indians) who were drawn to the link(area,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thunderbird_Archaeological_District by its rich natural resources. The artifacts found at these sites come from the link(Clovis Culture,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clovis_culture), thought to be among the earliest people to live in the Americas.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4914/45352821694_b01b7cca93_o_d.jpg)1699 - Burr Harrison and Giles Vandercastle visit the Piscataway village on Heater’s Island in the Potomac

The link(Piscataway,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piscataway_people) tribe settled in Fauquier County near Thoroughfare Gap in the late 1600s before moving into Loudoun County. Virginia officials Harrison and Vandercastle found a fort and 27 cabins providing shelter for approximately 300 people. This is one of the earliest recorded link(contacts,https://mdhistoricaltrust.wordpress.com/2015/04/24/heaters-island-piscataway) between Native Americans and white settlers in the Heritage Area.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4878/46077139191_d129c0a0f3_z_d.jpg)August 22, 1722 - Treaty of Albany is ratified

Governor Brad Rittenhouse.marshAlexander Spotswood of Virginia, the five Iroquois nations, and remnants of the Powhatan tribes agreed to a treaty, accepting that the Native Americans would keep their settlements west of the Blue Ridge Mountains. This treaty allowed white settlers to move into the Virginia Piedmont.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4832/44261245520_c6b57835fe_o_d.png)1731- An act of the Virginia General Assembly creates Prince William County The new county was formed out of portions of King George and Stafford Counties

The county takes its name from link(Prince William Augustus,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cumberland), Duke of Cumberland — a son of link(King George II,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain).

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4877/45165921535_1986953ffe_o_d.jpg)1733 - The Village of Waterford is founded

Quaker leader link(Amos Janney,https://www.waterfordhistory.org/history/waterford-origins) moved to the Loudoun Valley in search of fertile land. Other Quakers soon joined him and founded the village of Waterford. The town soon had a mill, meeting house, and several shops. Within ten years, a second Quaker village — Goose Creek — was established in Loudoun County. Today both Waterford and Goose Creek (now called Lincoln) remain relatively unchanged and stand as models of historic preservation.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4907/46025351242_f2fa8d12c6_o_d.jpg)1742 - Chapman-Beverly Mill is built in Thoroughfare Gap

Jonathan and Nathaniel Chapman built the link(mill,https://www.chapmansmill.org) and enlarged it in 1758. The mill processed wheat and corn, helping Northern Virginia’s farms prosper. Crops that passed through the mill went to Alexandria, where they could be shipped and sold to markets around the world.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4857/45167027405_9655039bba_o_d.jpg)1748 - Greenway Court Established

Located near White Post in Clarke County, Greenway Court was the home of link(Thomas Fairfax,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Fairfax), Sixth Lord Fairfax. He owned the land stretching from the Rappahannock River to the Potomac River and from the Chesapeake Bay west to the Appalachian Mountains, an area also known as the Fairfax Grant. He lived at link(Greenway Court,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenway_Court,_Virginia) from 1752 until his death in 1781.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4855/44259176870_5029ccbb7a_o_d.jpg)April 1755 - The Braddock Expedition marches through Loudoun County

In the spring of 1755 more than one thousand British soldiers landed in Alexandria under the command of General link(Edward Braddock,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Braddock); their mission was to drive the French from Fort Duquesne (modern Pittsburgh). Accompanying the force was a large number of Colonial troops and officers, among them George Washington, Daniel Boone, and link(Daniel Morgan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Morgan). A portion of the army marched through Loudoun County from Sugarland Run, through Leesburg, and westward to Keyes Gap. Braddock and his men met with disaster later that summer at the Battle of Monongahela.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4805/44275543270_ce441b1798_o_d.jpg)1757 - Loudoun County is created out of portions of Fairfax County, with the town of Leesburg as its seat

The County takes its name from link(John Campbell,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Campbell,_4th_Earl_of_Loudoun), Fourth Earl of Loudoun — a Scottish lord and Commander in Chief of British and Colonial forces for part of the French and Indian War. Leesburg was named for the former governor of the Colony of Virginia, link(Thomas Lee,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Lee_%28Virginia_colonist%29).

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4848/45180270045_9ae6e97035_o_d.jpg)1759 Fauquier County is established out of the western part of Prince William County

Fauquier County is named after link(Francis Fauquier,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Fauquier), the Virginia Colony’s Lieutenant Governor from 1758 until his death in 1768.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4814/45167027795_f48fea31a3_o_d.jpg)1773 Thomas Marshall builds Oak Hill

link(John Marshall,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Marshall), future Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, became the owner of Oak Hill in 1785. He owned the home until 1835. 1774 - The Loudoun and Fauquier Resolves Citizens of Loudoun and Fauquier Counties met at their courthouses to draw up a list of complaints against the British. These “Resolves” opposed the British occupation of Boston and the taxation of the colonies without representation in Parliament.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4917/46042332422_a449584af3_o_d.jpg)November 7, 1775 - Dunmore’s Proclamation is signed

link(Proclamation,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunmore%27s_Proclamation) declared that enslaved people who joined the British armed forces would be freed. Several slaves from the Heritage Area followed Dunmore’s words and fought in the Ethiopian Regiment

title: The Revolutionary Era
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4817/31149524807_985af31af5_o_d.jpg)August 12, 1776 - Declaration of Independence read in Loudoun County

The newly approved Declaration of Independence was Click link(read,https://loudounnow.com/2015/11/12/loudouns-revolutionary-spirit-memorialized-at-courthouse) to Loudoun’s citizens from the courthouse steps in Leesburg.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4806/46025352332_0115d68501_o_d.jpg)1780 - John Champe’s secret mission

Loudoun County native link(John Champe,https://www.loudounhistory.org/history/revolutionary-war-john-champe) was chosen to undertake a dangerous secret mission. He was ordered to pose as an American deserter, join the British army, and kidnap the turncoat link(Benedict Arnold,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedict_Arnold). Champe did become a member of the British Army but did not capture Arnold. He escaped back to the Continental Army with valuable intelligence and became a hero.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4826/46088749561_d4610e5eb5_o_d.jpg)1781 - Revolutionary War Marches

In June 1781 American General link(Anthony Wayne,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Wayne) led a column of Pennsylvanians through Loudoun and Fauquier Counties to reinforce the link(Marquis de Lafayette,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert_du_Motier,_Marquis_de_Lafayette) in central Virginia. In the fall, nearly 3,000 British, German, and Loyalist prisoners from Yorktown marched through Fauquier County to Ashby’s Gap to prisoner of war camps near Winchester.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4813/32217745308_ef95d8d1d3_o_d.jpg)1782 - Daniel Morgan returns to Clarke County

link(Daniel Morgan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Morgan) moved to Virginia as a young man and settled near Battletown (now Berryville). During the Revolutionary War, he became one of George Washington’s best commanders, and he played a critical role at the Battles of Saratoga and Cowpens. He returned to Clarke County after the war, building a new home named Saratoga near Boyce, as well as the Burwell-Morgan Mill in Millwood. Devices known as “hornet’s balls” crushed ore in order to allow miners to get access to the gold.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4828/44259175670_59ca13df0f_o_d.jpg)June 25, 1788 - Virginia ratifies the United States Constitution

Virginia Delegate link(Edmund Randolph,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmund_Randolph) sought his state’s link(ratification,https://www.usconstitution.net/rat_va.html) of the Constitution, and worked to achieve it. He later became the first Attorney General of the United States under President Washington. Randolph died in 1813 and is buried at link(Old Chapel,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Chapel_%28Millwood,_Virginia%29) in Millwood.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4831/46039344662_5b51f50bbb_o_d.jpg)1803 - Loudoun’s John A. Binns publishes “A Treatise on Practical Farming”

Binns' "Loudoun System" of farming promoted deep plowing, crop rotation, and the use of lime, gypsum, and manure. Binns’ progressive ideas spurred agricultural progress throughout the country, especially in the South.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4855/46042231202_e9e0c306e6_o_d.jpg)1803–1812 - Ashby’s Gap Turnpike

Work took place on Ashby’s Gap Turnpike, from the Little River west to the Shenandoah River, including building the link(Goose Creek Bridge,https://bridgehunter.com/va/loudoun/bh50429).

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4808/45350918314_22716130e5_o_d.jpg)1807–1809 - Aldie Mill is constructed

Charles Fenton Mercer built the mill, the only one of its kind with double-overshot water wheels.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4911/44273635890_edea7fa85d_o_d.jpg)1810 - Warrenton is incorporated

Fauquier’s county link(seat,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warrenton,_Virginia)  is named for Revolutionary War hero link(Joseph Warren,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Warren).

title: The Anitbellum Era
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4912/31152626147_a9ebd95d97_z_d.jpg)1814 - Refuge in Leesburg

When the British occupied Washington on August 24, 1814, President link(James Madison,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Madison) fled the capital. Some of the nation’s most treasured historical documents were taken to Leesburg for safe keeping, including the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence. Tradition says that they were stored at Rokeby. Madison himself went to Belmont.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4911/44259175910_97bfc8f8c7_o_d.jpg)1818 - Gold Rush in Fauquier County

In 1818, the first commercial gold mine in Fauquier County was created. Located near Sumerduck in southern Fauquier County, the Union Gold Mine was operated by Cornish immigrants who dug the mine’s 5,000-foot shaft. Within a few years at least 18 other mines were in operation. Mining temporarily halted during the Civil War, but resumed in the late 1860s and continued until the early 20th century.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4893/44259174280_25d1c71277_o_d.jpg)1823 - President James Monroe writes a draft of the Monroe Doctrine at Oak Hill

link(James Monroe,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Monroe) owned Oak Hill from the 1790s until his death in 1831. He likely wrote parts of the link(Monroe Doctrine,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monroe_Doctrine) from his Oak Hill office.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4817/32274779178_b74ab68617_o_d.png)August 1825 - Lafayette Returns

To celebrate the 50th anniversary of the American Revolution President Monroe invited the link(Marquis de Lafayette,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert_du_Motier,_Marquis_de_Lafayette) on a celebratory tour of America. The “Hero of Two Worlds” arrived in Loudoun on August 6th, stopping first to visit James Monroe’s Oak Hill. On the 9th his arrival in Leesburg was announced by cannon fire and more than 1,500 townspeople came out to greet him. A few weeks later the Marquis visited Fauquier County, where he stayed at Norris Tavern in Warrenton before returning to Washington.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4818/45234238455_2a2f15fa8d_o_d.png)1836 - Clarke and Warren counties established

Both were part of Frederick County before becoming separate jurisdictions.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4884/46025350082_29b20d27d7_o_d.jpg)1836 - Margaret Mercer establishes Belmont Academy

The antislavery Mercer founded and taught at this liberal Christian school just east of Leesburg for local young ladies.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4872/46145877811_0df2786f11_o_d.jpg)1840 - Piedmont Hunt established

The oldest foxhunt in the United States began at Old Welbourne near Middleburg.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4842/44329314090_260e9911c8_o_d.jpg)1851–1859 - Construction of the Manassas Gap Railroad

By its full completion in 1859, the link(railroad,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manassas_Gap_Railroad) extended from Manassas Junction to Mount Jackson in the Shenandoah Valley.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4903/32275056228_e9ba43016e_b_d.jpg)1853 - Upperville Colt and Horse Show founded

Richard Dulany and others began this link(show,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upperville_Colt_%26_Horse_Show) to promote the good care of horses. It is the oldest horse show in the United States.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4856/46145956571_a0290451c0_b_d.jpg)December 24, 1855 - The Wanzer slave escape begins

Frank Wanzer, Barnaby Grigsby, and four other enslaved people escaped north from farms near Aldie and Middleburg in one of the most famous episodes on the Underground Railroad.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4902/31136384077_0d32a9008e_o_d.jpg)April 6, 1859 - Daniel Dangerfield secures his freedom

Daniel Dangerfield was enslaved on farms and at the Aldie Mill before making his escape to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. Once there, link(Dangerfield,https://www.visitloudoun.org/things-to-do/civil-war/the-people/enslaved-who-escaped-to-freedom) found a wife and had a family. Dangerfield’s former owners caught him and brought him to Philadelphia for trial. Philadelphia’s abolitionists rallied and won his freedom in April 1859.

title: The Civil War
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4910/46202193581_5cd6007e3f_o_d.jpg)October 16, 1859 – December 2, 1859 - John Brown’s Raid on Harpers Ferry

John Brown’s plan to start an insurrection that would end slavery forever in the United States lasted only 36 hours and failed. Brown himself was captured and executed by the Commonwealth of Virginia. His raid spread fear and panic throughout Northern Virginia. It also inspired some slaves to act against their owners, including some near Berryville who managed to burn $11,000 worth of property on November 12, 1859. Clarke County’s link(Richard Parker,https://ohiohistoryhost.org/ohiomemory/archives/1414) presided over Brown’s trial. Brown was executed on December 2, 1859. link(Wikipedia article,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Brown%27s_raid_on_Harpers_Ferry)

Former Fauquier and Prince William County slave link(Dangerfield Newby,https://blackpast.org/aah/newby-dangerfield-f-1815-1859) joined John Brown in a desperate attempt to free his family but died in vain.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4852/44259175530_9ca6e791da_o_d.jpg)April 17, 1861 - Virginia’s State Convention adopts an Ordinance of Secession

Both of Loudoun’s delegates and Clarke’s delegate voted against adopting the ordinance, but it eventually passed by a vote of 88–55. The people of Virginia upheld the link(Convention,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Secession_Convention_of_1861)’s decision on May 23, 1861, by a vote of 125,950 to 20,373.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4882/46025350252_833e839ef7_o_d.jpg)June 1, 1861 - John Quincy Marr becomes the first Confederate officer killed in the Civil War

Marr commanded a company of soldiers stationed at Fairfax Court House. Union cavalry moved into the town and briefly fought with Marr’s Confederates. link(Marr,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Quincy_Marr) died in the fighting.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4868/45471409504_340602b802_o_d.jpg)July 19, 1861 – July 21, 1861 - Confederate troops move to Manassas Junction by rail, the first time such an event occurred in American history

Confederate soldiers from the Shenandoah Valley boarded trains on the link(Manassas Gap Railroad,https://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Manassas_Gap_Railroad_During_the_Civil_War) at Piedmont Station (Delaplane) en route to the first major battle of the Civil War near Manassas Junction. Their timely arrival helped win the day for the Confederate Army.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4819/45350923874_9219ff746f_o_d.jpg)October 21, 1861 - Battle of Ball’s Bluff

The fierce link(battle,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Ball%27s_Bluff) outside Leesburg was a Confederate victory, with Union troops running down the bluff to the Potomac River. The commander of the Union forces, link(Edward Baker,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Dickinson_Baker), who was a U.S. Senator from Oregon, was killed. He is the only sitting U.S. Senator to be killed in battle.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4816/45350916884_3c6c71d95e_o_d.jpg)May 3, 1862 - Robert Eden Scott is killed by Union deserters

Robert Eden Scott served as one of two Fauquier County delegates to the Virginia State Convention in 1861. He tracked down two Union deserters in Fauquier County. One of them shot Scott, who died nearly instantly. link(Scott,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Eden_Scott) was so highly thought of that President Lincoln had considered him for his cabinet.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4901/46195457531_e8e4aa64ce_o_d.jpg)May 23, 1862 - Battle of Front Royal

Confederate forces under Stonewall Jackson defeated a Union force at link(Front Royal,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Front_Royal), opening the door to Jackson’s capture of Winchester two days later.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4864/46025352952_1c19b4060d_o_d.jpg)June 20, 1862 - The Loudoun Rangers are formed

link(Samuel Means,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_C._Means) and his Unionist link(Loudoun Rangers,https://www.loudounhistory.org/history/loudoun-cw-rangers) were officially mustered into Federal service. The Rangers were the only unit raised in present-day Virginia to serve in the United States Army during the Civil War. The Rangers suffered heavily in a fight with link(Elijah V. White,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elijah_V._White)’s Confederates at the Waterford Baptist Church on August 27, 1862.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4899/31136384297_85f55da032_o_d.jpg)August 19, 1862 - Escaped slaves are photographed in the Rappahannock River

link(Timothy O’Sullivan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timothy_H._O%27Sullivan) captured a series of images showing five men and women seeking freedom within Union Army lines along the Rappahannock River. This image is one of the most widely used photographs from the Civil War. The photograph was taken near Tinpot Run Ford, just downstream from Remington in the Rappahannock River.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4878/44259176620_c4edb7119a_o_d.jpg)August 28, 1862 – August 30, 1862 - Battle of Second Manassas

Union and Confederate armies once again found themselves squaring off outside of Manassas Junction. This second and larger battle at link(Manassas,https://www.history.com/topics/american-civil-war/second-battle-of-bull-run) involved 125,000 troops. Some 22,000 were either killed, wounded, or captured in three days of fighting.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4862/31256352297_d1fe0a6227_o_d.jpg)October 26, 1862 – November 7, 1862 - Loudoun Valley Campaign

Union and Confederate forces marched and fought in the Loudoun Valley in the wake of the link(Battle of Antietam,https://www.history.com/topics/american-civil-war/battle-of-antietam). Union army commander link(George B. McClellan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_B._McClellan) was relieved of his command and replaced by link(Ambrose Burnside,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambrose_Burnside) at Rectortown on November 7, 1862.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4830/44259175390_51742284aa_o_d.jpg)June 10, 1863 - Mosby’s Rangers are officially formed

link(John Mosby,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_S._Mosby) officially formed link(Co. A &, 43rd Battalion of Virginia Cavalry,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/43rd_Battalion,_Virginia_Cavalry) at Rector’s Crossroads (above). Mosby’s command operated for 28 months in Northern Virginia, gathering intelligence and harassing Union supply lines throughout the region.

booklet(Booklet on Mosby's life,mcbook)

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4908/45350923394_a1d53d63e5_o_d.jpg)June 17, 1863 – June 21, 1863 - Battles of Aldie, Middleburg, and Upperville

During the second Confederate invasion of the North, opposing Union and Confederate cavalry clashed inconclusively in the Loudoun Valley in link(Aldie,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Aldie), link(Middleburg,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Middleburg), and link(Upperville,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Upperville) for five days. The two armies faced each other again at Gettysburg in July.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4843/45163512555_f991f4aa1b_o_d.jpg)May 28, 1864 - The Waterford News is published for the first time

Three Quaker girls in Waterford published eight issues of a Union sympathizing link(newspaper,https://ead.lib.virginia.edu/vivaxtf/view?docId=tbl/viletbl00027.xml) within Confederate territory. The proceeds from the newspaper supported sick and wounded Union soldiers. Some sources claim the venture raised more than $1,000.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4894/46195457721_47c37fd210_o_d.jpg)July 18, 1864 - Battle of Cool Spring

Following the Confederate move into Maryland under General Jubal Early in July 1864 and the brief fighting in Washington, D.C., the Southerners recrossed the Potomac River near Leesburg and headed to the Shenandoah Valley. Pursuing Federal forces caught up with the Confederates along the Shenandoah River on the Blue Ridge Mountain’s western slopes. The resulting link(battle at Cool Spring,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Cool_Spring), a Confederate victory, was the largest battle of the war in Clarke County.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4915/45471409624_c7d1ce6752_o_d.jpg)September 16, 1864 - Thomas Laws and Rebecca Wright aid the Union war effort in the Shenandoah Valley

link(Thomas Laws,https://www.localdvm.com/news/virginia/story-of-enslaved-clarke-county-man-who-acted-as-spy-during-the-civil-war/905658468), a Clarke County slave, helped Union link(Gen. Philip Sheridan,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Sheridan) learn about Confederate forces in the Shenandoah Valley. Laws walked through Confederate lines and met with Quaker schoolteacher link(Rebecca Wright,https://www.civilwarwomenblog.com/rebecca-wright) in Winchester. Wright supplied Laws with intelligence about the Confederates and Laws brought that back to Sheridan. This contributed significantly to the Union successes in the Shenandoah Valley in the fall of 1864.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4883/46152074682_e25d93260c_o_d.jpg)September 23, 1864 - Mosby’s Rangers executed

Union soldiers executed six of Mosby’s Rangers in the streets of Front Royal by order of United States link(General Alfred Torbert,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Thomas_Archimedes_Torbert). One more was hanged on October 14. The executions took place following a Confederate raid on a Union ambulance train near Front Royal.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4892/32220391218_c217a8e355_z_d.jpg)November 7, 1864 - Mosby retaliates

In retaliation for the Front Royal executions, John S. Mosby ordered the executions of seven Union soldiers, selected by lottery, outside Berryville. Ultimately, three Union prisoners were hanged, two were shot (and survived), and two escaped.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4880/31136384377_5aedf0c9fb_o_d.jpg)November 28, 1864 – December 2, 1864 - The Burning Raid

Federal cavalrymen rode through the Loudoun and northern Crooked Run valleys burning barns, mills, and stables to prevent the further use of both valleys as a staging point for Mosby’s Rangers. During the five-day raid, an estimated $6.4 million (in 2017 currency) of property was torched or carried off by the cavalrymen.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4882/44259177240_a0d6d2d923_o_d.jpg)March 3, 1865 - Freedmen’s Bureau established

The U.S. Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen and Abandoned Lands, known better as the link(Freedmen’s Bureau,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedmen%27s_Bureau), began working with former slaves and poor whites in the South. Freedmen’s Bureau offices were established in Middleburg, Manassas, Warrenton, and Front Royal.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4804/46195457661_761a6d2a87_o_d.jpg)April 9, 1865 - Lee surrenders at Appomattox

link(Robert E. Lee,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_E._Lee) surrendered his Confederate Army to link(Ulysses S. Grant,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant) at link(Appomattox Courthouse,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House) effectively signaling the end of the Civil War. Mosby disbanded his command in Salem, today’s Marshall, on April 21, 1865.

title: Reconstruction and Social Reform
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4832/46041474152_5b8fac08d2_z_d.jpg)July 1869 - African American veteran John Holmes establishes a freedmen’s school in Millwood

Civil War veteran link(John Holmes,https://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Holmes_Joseph_R_ca_1838-May_3_1869) lost a leg while fighting for the Federal cause in the Civil War. By July 1869, Holmes was teaching at the African American school in Millwood.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4834/46025350662_f62a8ae47f_o_d.jpg)September 19, 1870 - Josephine City is formed

31 acres of land formerly belonging to the estate of Edward McCormick was auctioned off to black residents of Berryville. The land later became known as link(Josephine City,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephine_City_Historic_District)

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4814/46153955632_30cdd1dae1_o_d.jpg)1873 - Manassas incorporated

Manassas became Prince William’s county seat in 1892.


pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4915/46153954892_4c06564167_o_d.jpg)1890 - The Loudoun County Emancipation Association founded

A handful of men meeting in Hamilton sought a formalized way to memorialize the announcement of Lincoln’s Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation (September 22, 1862). They formed the Loudoun County Emancipation Association. The Association purchased land south of Purcellville to hold its celebrations, and celebrated Emancipation Day until 1967.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4821/46204591541_b6a2819563_o_d.jpg)1902 - The Prohibition and Evangelical Association of Loudoun formed

Religious gatherings known as Bush Meetings took place in Purcellville beginning in 1877. Meetings became formalized under the title of the Prohibition and Evangelical Association of Loudoun. Bush Meetings ended in Loudoun in the early 1930s.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4899/31136384477_23de12dae3_o_d.jpg)November 1905 -The Great Hound Match of 1905

To end a heated debate about whether American or English hounds were better suited to foxhunting in North America, Harry Worcester Smith and his Grafton Hunt (American hounds) faced off against Henry Higginson and the Middlesex Hunt (English hounds). The match had a wide following. At the end of nearly two weeks of hunting, neither Hunt caught a fox, but the judges awarded the victory to Smith and his American-bred hounds. The match greatly elevated Northern Virginia’s profile as hunt country.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4895/46153955242_1b60bc93df_o_d.jpg)January 13, 1909 - President Theodore Roosevelt sets a record

link(Theodore Roosevelt,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt) and several aides completed a one-day, 104-mile horseback ride from Washington, D.C., to Warrenton and back. President Roosevelt feasted on a lunch at the Warren Green Hotel, made a speech, and continued his ride back to Washington. “It was bully!” Roosevelt said on his arrival at the Executive Mansion.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4895/46041463212_2c9c5a6fe3_o_d.jpg)November 22, 1909 - Fire sweeps through downtown Warrenton

A massive fire devastated Warrenton, burning 26 buildings and leaving 14 families homeless.

title: The World War Era
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4905/31152627707_3da9ea72bd_b_d.jpg)April 6, 1917 – November 11, 1918 - America participates in World War I

World War I’s shockwaves reached far and wide, claiming the lives of 122 citizens of the Heritage Area. Loudoun native link(Westmoreland Davis,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westmoreland_Davis) served as Virginia’s wartime governor.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4807/44259175240_b1d8a5275e_o_d.jpg)September 13, 1921 - Freedwoman Mary Mallory dies at the age of 108

Mary Mallory spent the first 52 years of her life as an enslaved woman at Morven Park but lived as a free person for her last 56 years. She lived out her life in Leesburg and is buried in the Mount Zion Community Cemetery.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4827/32220399808_457cdc2aec_o_d.jpg)1926 - Harry Flood Byrd, Sr. purchases Rosemont

Virginia Governor (1926-1930) and Senator (1933-1965) Harry Flood Byrd, Sr. purchased Rosemont outside Berryville. He moved in by 1929. Byrd is best known for his improvements to Virginia’s highways and tourism sites, but also for his role in instituting a “link(massive resistance,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massive_resistance)” policy in Virginia to oppose the integration of the state’s schools.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4833/31152625477_5314b7b976_b_d.jpg)1936 - Skyline Drive extended to Front Royal

The scenic link(Skyline Drive,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skyline_Drive) running along the spine of the Blue Ridge Mountains reached Front Royal. It took eight years (1931-1939) to complete the roadway as part of the Works Progress Administration’s New Deal initiatives.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4855/46204591751_801f211f26_z_d.jpg)December 7, 1941 – September 2, 1945 - Local men and women participate in World War II

link(World War II,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II) had an impact on the whole globe, including the Heritage Area. Clarke, Fauquier, Loudoun, Prince William, and Warren counties lost 288 residents in the war while citizens at home endured rationing, “victory” link(speed limits,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Maximum_Speed_Law), and constant worrying about their loved ones far away.

title: Cold War to the Present
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4860/31265909427_282af6b5dc_b_d.jpg)August 1948 - President Truman visits Ball’s Bluff

link(Harry Truman,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_S._Truman came to Leesburg to visit Secretary of State link(George C. Marshall,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Marshall). Together, the two toured the Ball’s Bluff battlefield before returning to Marshall’s home and discussed China, Russia, public people and their lives. Marshall lived at Dodona Manor in Leesburg from 1941 to his death in 1959.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4842/45350919254_d884bcf7da_o_d.jpg)September 1958 – February 18, 1959 - Warren County High School is a symbol of “massive resistance” and integration

Ordered to integrate in the wake of the landmark case Brown v. Board of Education, Virginia Governor Almond instead closed Warren County High School in September 1958 as part of the state’s “link(massive resistance,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massive_resistance)” policy to integration. After the school reopened, 23 African American students enrolled on February 18, 1959.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4912/32203862308_ff6b3d961d_o_d.jpg)February 1961 - The Kennedy family arrives in Hunt Country

Spurred by a love of horse country, President link(John F. Kennedy,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy) and First Lady link(Jackie,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis) leased Glen Ora, south of Middleburg, as their weekend retreat. The Kennedys were frequent visitors to Middleburg and later built their own home, Wexford, south of Atoka. The family did not spend much time at Wexford. Shortly after its completion, President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4848/46216283741_b744016196_z_d.jpg)April 9, 1961 - Restaurants in Middleburg are desegregated

Hoping to take advantage of the news media flocking to Middleburg to cover President Kennedy, two Howard University students took seats at Flournoy’s Drugstore. The owners refused them service. The rejected students boldly sought to organize a larger sit-in that coincided with the Kennedy’s — and the media’s — next visit to Middleburg. Seeking to avoid a confrontation in front of the President and spare Middleburg the embarrassment, restaurant owners backed down. On April 9, two local black customers sat down at Flournoy’s Drugstore and were served.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4908/31136383987_3dc7b3588c_o_d.jpg)November 17, 1962 - Dulles Airport opens

Dulles International Airport’s construction and opening spurred the growth of eastern Loudoun’s population, but it altered the area’s agricultural character. link(Dulles,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Dulles_International_Airport) attracted large commercial development by the 1990s.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4869/31152622317_eaf31a0f81_z_d.jpg)September 13, 1967 – September 17, 1967 - Martin Luther King, Jr. and other prominent leaders organize the Poor People’s Campaign

Meeting at Airlie outside of Warrenton, Civil Rights leader Martin Luther link(King,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr.), Jr. and the Southern Christian Leadership  link(Conference,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Christian_Leadership_Conference) planned the Poor People’s link(Campaign,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poor_People%27s_Campaign), a movement organized to achieve economic justice in the United States for underprivileged individuals.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4863/31265909157_63e9a1881f_o_d.jpg)December 1, 1974 – 11:09 am - TWA Flight 514 crashes at Mt. Weather

Diverted to Dulles International Airport and beginning its descent on the stormy day of December 1, 1974, link(TWA Flight 514,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TWA_Flight_514) collided into the western side of the Blue Ridge Mountains near Mt. Weather at 11:09 am, killing all 92 passengers and crew members. The crash brought unwanted attention to the top secret government facility at link(Mt. Weather,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Weather_Emergency_Operations_Center), a relocation site for government officials in the case of national disaster.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4875/32307611238_09eb2dfeb3_b_d.jpg)1995 - The Mosby Heritage Area Association is founded

MHAA’s mission is to educate and advocate for the preservation of the extraordinary historical landscape and culture of the Mosby Heritage Area for future generations.
